poem:
### Crossing Paths

The bears in Sierra Madre
shuffle through our doorways, 
leave wet prints on linoleum tiles,
a curious twang of fur
on morning breath cups.
We lament the intrusion,
yet it's we who wandered
into their ancient dens,
erecting walls,
fences,
dreams in the forest's cradle,
while their nocturnes 
echo in the unwritten rooms of dusk.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "California bears make themselves at home as humans build closer to nature Humans are building homes closer to the forest in southern California, and bears are putting their foot, or their paw, down. Residents in Sierra Madre, a city neighboring the more than 700,000-acre (283,280-hectare) Angeles national forest, have had black bears break into their homes, cars and yards. It’s also no coincidence that residents in the area might be seeing more bears as winter". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
